media.caption: This satellite panorama encompasses both island groups of the Paracel Islands. Image courtesy of NASA.

fields.name: Background
fields.content: The Paracel Islands are surrounded by productive fishing grounds and by potential oil and gas reserves. In 1932, French Indochina annexed the islands and set up a weather station on Pattle Island; maintenance was continued by its successor, Vietnam. China has occupied all the Paracel Islands since 1974, when its troops seized a South Vietnamese garrison occupying the western islands. China built a military installation on Woody Island with an airfield and artificial harbor, and has scattered garrisons on some of the other islands. The Paracel islands also are claimed by Taiwan and Vietnam.

fields.name: Location
fields.content: Southeastern Asia, group of small islands and reefs in the South China Sea, about one-third of the way from central Vietnam to the northern Philippines

fields.name: Area
fields.content:
total: 8 sq km ca.

land: 7.75 sq km ca.

water: 0 sq km

fields.name: Area - comparative
fields.content: land area is about 13 times the size of the National Mall in Washington, DC

fields.name: Elevation
fields.content:
highest point: unnamed location on Rocky Island 14 m

lowest point: South China Sea 0 m

subfields.content: unnamed location on Rocky Island 14 m

subfields.title: highest point

fields.name: Population distribution
fields.content: a population of over 1,000 Chinese resides on Woody Island, the largest of the Paracels; there are scattered Chinese garrisons on some other islands

fields.name: Geography - note
fields.content: composed of 130 small coral islands and reefs divided into the northeast Amphitrite Group and the western Crescent Group

fields.name: Population
fields.content:
1,440 (July 2014 est.)

note: Chinese activity has increased in recent years, particularly on Woody Island, where the population exceeds 1,000; there are scattered Chinese garrisons on some other islands
fields.field_note: note: Chinese activity has increased in recent years, particularly on Woody Island, where the population exceeds 1,000; there are scattered Chinese garrisons on some other islands

fields.name: Population distribution
fields.content: a population of over 1,000 Chinese resides on Woody Island, the largest of the Paracels; there are scattered Chinese garrisons on some other islands

fields.name: Environment - current issues
fields.content: China's use of dredged sand and coral to build artificial islands harms reef systems; ongoing human activities, including military operations, infrastructure construction, and tourism endangers local ecosystem including birds, fish, marine mammals, and marine reptiles

fields.name: Country name
fields.content:
conventional long form: none

conventional short form: Paracel Islands

etymology: Portuguese navigators began to refer to the "Ilhas do Pracel" in the 16th century as a designation of low lying islets, sandbanks, and reefs scattered over a wide area; over time the name changed to "parcel" and then "paracel"

subfields.name: etymology
subfields.content: Portuguese navigators began to refer to the "Ilhas do Pracel" in the 16th century as a designation of low lying islets, sandbanks, and reefs scattered over a wide area; over time the name changed to "parcel" and then "paracel"

subfields.title: etymology

fields.name: Economic overview
fields.content: The islands have the potential for oil and gas development. Waters around the islands support commercial fishing, but the islands themselves are not populated on a permanent basis.

fields.name: Ports and terminals
fields.content: small Chinese port facilities on Woody Island and Duncan Island

fields.name: Military - note
fields.content: occupied by China, which is assessed to maintain 20 outposts in the Paracels (Antelope, Bombay, and North reefs; Drummond, Duncan, Lincoln, Middle, Money, North, Pattle, Quanfu, Robert, South, Tree, Triton, Woody, and Yagong islands; South Sand and West Sand; Observation Bank); the outposts range in size from one or two buildings to bases with significant military infrastructure; Woody Island is the main base in the Paracels and includes an airstrip with fighter aircraft hangers, naval facilities, surveillance radars, and defenses such as surface-to-air missiles and anti-ship cruise missiles; fighter aircraft have deployed to the island (2021)

fields.name: Disputes - international
fields.content: occupied by China, also claimed by Taiwan and Vietnam
